entries.meaning: The upper portion of a page (or other) layout.
examples: If you reduce the header of this document, the body will fit onto a single page.

entries.meaning: Text, or other visual information, used to mark off a quantity of text, often titling or summarizing it.
examples: Your header is too long; "Local Cannibals" will suffice.

entries.meaning: Text, or other visual information, that goes at the top of a column of information in a table.
examples: That column should have the header "payment status".

entries.meaning: (informal) A font, text style, or typesetting used for any of the above.
examples: Parts of speech belong in a level-three header. Level-two headers are reserved for the name of the language.

entries.meaning: (computing) The first part of a file or record that describes its contents.
examples: The header includes an index, an identifier, and a pointer to the next entry.

entries.meaning: (networking) the first part of a packet or stream, often containing its address and descriptors.
examples: The encapsulation layer adds an eight-byte header and a two-byte trailer to each packet.

entries.meaning: (masonry) A brick that is laid sideways at the top of a wall or within the brickwork with the short side showing.
examples: This wall has four header courses.

entries.meaning: A horizontal structural or finish piece over an opening.
A machine that separates and gathers the heads of grain etc.
examples: They fed the bale into the header.

entries.meaning: (soccer) The act of hitting the ball with the head.
examples: His header for the goal followed a perfect corner kick.

entries.meaning: A headlong fall, jump or dive.
examples: The clown tripped over the other clown and took a header.

entries.meaning: A raised tank that supplies water at constant pressure, especially to a central heating and hot water system.
A pipe which connects several smaller pipes.
examples: Common practice is to use plastic pipes with iron headers.

entries.meaning: The rodeo performer who drives the steer toward the heeler to be tied.
One who puts a head on something.

verbs.description: header (third-person singular simple present headers, present participle headering, simple past and past participle headered)

entries.meaning: (sports, transitive) To strike (a ball) with one's head.
